module sas

module containing the class Sas

class sas.Sas

class sas.Sas(pdb_in)

Class for computing solvent accessible surface from pdb files. Dependencies: pdbatom, numpy, math, scipy. The solvent accessible surface is calculated as a list of dots. First, for each atom, an exclusion sphere around the atom (with radius equal to the vanderwaalsradius of the atom plus the probe radius), is covered with dots. Next, dots of the atom which are occluded by exclusion spheres of other atoms are eliminated.

Parameters:

  • pdb_in (str) – path to pdb file with input structure

  • atoms (list of PdbAtom, length n_atoms.) – list of atoms as read from pdb_in

  • n_atoms (int) – number of atoms read from pdb_in

  • atom_radius (list of float, length n_atoms.) – list of atom vanderwaals radii

  • atom_position (numpy.array with shape (n_atoms,3)) – array holding atom coordinates

  • element_radius (dict()) – dictionary with atom vanderwaalsradii (values, float) of chemical elements (keys, str)

  • neighbourlist_cutoff (float) – for finding neighbouring atoms (Angstrom)

  • probe_radius (float) – radius of rolling sphere defining solvent accessible surface area (Angstrom)

  • dots_per_atom (int) – number of dots used to approximate solvent acessible surface around each atom

  • neighbourlist (list of list of int) – for each atom a list of atom indices of neighbouring atoms (within neighbourlist_cutoff)

  • atom_dots (list of numpy.array (list length n_atoms), each with shape (dots_per_atom,3)) – coordinates of all dots, per atom

  • indices_selected_dots_per_atom (list (length n_atoms) of list of int) – indices for dots (from atom_dots) which are solvent acessible, per atom

  • self.ndots_sas (int) – total number of dots forming solvent acessible surface

Example:

# lets get the dots forming the surface accesible area of atom 3        
sas = sas.Sas("trimer.pdb")
all_dots = sas.atom_dots[3]
selected_dot_indices = sas.indices_selected_dots_per_atom[3]
n_surface_dots = len(selected_dot_indices)
surface_dots = [all_dots[i] for i in selected_dot_indices] # list of numpy arrays with shape (3,)
Sas.__init__(pdb_in)

Constructor. All computations are done immediately after calling the constructor.

Parameters:

pdb_in (str) – path to pdb file with input structure

Sas.set_default_parameter_values()

Sets these default parameter values:

  • probe_radius = 1.4 Angstrom

  • dots_per_atom = 50

  • neighbourlist_cutoff = 7.0 Angstrom

  • element_radius [‘C’] = 1.9 Angstrom

  • element_radius [‘N’]= 1.7 Angstrom

  • element_radius [‘O’] = 1.5 Angstrom

  • element_radius [‘S’] = 1.9 Angstrom

Sas.print_parameter_values()

Print values of probe_radius , dots_per_atom, neighbourlist_cutoff and the element_radius dict.

Sas.set_atom_position_and_radius_arrays()

Sets atom_position and atom_radius arrays, called after load_atoms.

Sas.build_neighbour_list()

Builds neighbour list for each atom. For each central atom, only atoms in its neighbourlist are use to identify dots that are solvent accessible.

Sas.load_atoms()

Reads pdb_file, sets atoms list and natoms. Only heavy atoms are retained.

Sas.generate_sphere_points(n)

Returns list of coordinates on a sphere of radius 1 using the Golden-Section Spiral algorithm.

Parameters:

n (int) – number of dots on the sphere

Returns:

list of coordinates of points covering a sphere of radius 1

Return type:

numpy.array shape (n,3)

Sas.compute_sas()

Finds which dots on the atom spheres are solvent-acessible. Sets indices_selected_dots_per_atom. Also sets the total number of solvent accessible atom dots for the entire structure, this is used by export_xyz

Sas.export_xyz(filename)

Exports solvent accessible dots to xyz file filename

Parameters:

filename (str) – path to xyz file
